prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
In continuum, with 10 minutes of observing time on each source, assuming an average declination of +25◦ (the source declination range from +24◦ to +30◦) and 6.6GHz bandwidth, dual polarization, we reach 1.1mJy/beam or 18mK (using the Observing Tool). The peak brightness temperature in the disks we propose to observe ranges from 2 to 6K at 1.3mm (Guilloteau et al. 2011). At 0.45mm their RJ brightness temperature should be at least equal to these values (if the unfavorable case that the disks are optically thick). Even accounting for a possible factor 20 decrease due to deviation from the RJ regime (most defavorable case of a 7K kinetic temperature), this would translate into a minimum of 100 mK, providing us sufficient signal-to-noise ratio (SNR = 8 in this case).
In fact, dynamic range will probably limit the noise. After self-calibration, a dynamic range of 200 should be readily achievable, which, using the peak brightness of 6 K (Rayleigh Jeans) would give a noise level around 30 mK, still sufficient for our measurement.
We use a FDM band to simultaneously observe the CO 6-5 with a spectral resolution of 0.2 km/s. The angular resolution of 0.4''-0.5'' is necessary to resolve out the radial gradient of dust properties.

In continuum, with 10 minutes of observing time on each source, assuming an average declination of +25◦ (the source declination range from +24◦ to +30◦) and 6.6GHz bandwidth, dual polarization, we reach 1.1mJy/beam or 18mK (using the Observing Tool). The peak brightness temperature in the disks we propose to observe ranges from 2 to 6K at 1.3mm (Guilloteau et al. 2011). At 0.45mm their RJ brightness temperature should be at least equal to these values (if the unfavorable case that the disks are optically thick). Even accounting for a possible factor 20 decrease due to deviation from the RJ regime (most defavorable case of a 7K kinetic temperature), this would translate into a minimum of 100 mK, providing us sufficient signal-to-noise ratio (SNR = 8 in this case).
In fact, dynamic range will probably limit the noise. After self-calibration, a dynamic range of 200 should be readily achievable, which, using the peak brightness of 6 K (Rayleigh Jeans) would give a noise level around 30 mK, still sufficient for our measurement.
We use a FDM band to simultaneously observe the CO 6-5 with a spectral resolution of 0.2 km/s. The angular resolution of 0.4''-0.5'' is necessary to resolve out the radial gradient of dust properties.

At 3mm, the continuum flux is on the order of 10-20 mJy. Spending 12min on each source will provide a sensitivy of 0.03mJy in a beam of 0.45''. For a 10 mJy source of size 3'' and assuming a uniform distribution, the resulting SNR per beam would be around 50. This is enough to allow analysis with the high SNR maps at 0.5 mm. The angular resolution of 0.4''-0.5'' is necessary to resolve out the radial gradient of dust properties. We need to have the same angular resolution in B3 and B9.

At 3mm, the continuum flux is on the order of 10-20 mJy. Spending 12min on each source will provide a sensitivy of 0.03mJy in a beam of 0.45''. For a 10 mJy source of size 3'' and assuming a uniform distribution, the resulting SNR per beam would be around 50. This is enough to allow analysis with the high SNR maps at 0.5 mm. The angular resolution of 0.4''-0.5'' is necessary to resolve out the radial gradient of dust properties. We need to have the same angular resolution in B3 and B9.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The gas and dust properties (temperatures, densities...) of gas-rich proto-planetary disks are key parameters in the formation of planetary systems. Among these fundamental parameters, the dust temperature still only relies on modeling. We propose a direct temperature measurement of the mm-emitting dust using resolved images from ALMA on a sample of 6 TTauri disks. We will use ALMA with an angular resolution of 0.4'' to image the 6 targets in continuum at 3 and 0.5mm. Combined with the existing EVLA, IRAM and/or CARMA data, this unique data set will provide the temperature profile of the large dust particles which make the bulk of the mm/submm thermal emission.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Circumstellar disks, exoplanets and the solar system

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: IRAM Grenoble, Institute of Millimetric Radioastronomy (IRAM)
Centro de Radioastronomia y Astrofisica, Universidad Nacional Autonomo de Mexico
